rsbNotes.title: 2 Sam 12:1
rsbNotes.text:
12:1 the Lord sent Nathan. The prophets were servants of the word of God, which has authority even over kings. The prophets needed courage and were sometimes in sharp conflict with the kings (1 Kin. 22:8; 2 Kin. 1:3, 4; Mark 6:17; cf. Acts 7:52).

one rich and the other poor. The rich man is David and the poor man is Uriah. The parable was also fulfilled by Ahab and Jezebel against Naboth (1 Kin. 21:1–14).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Sam 12:3
rsbNotes.text: 12:3 like a daughter to him. The verse ends with the Hebrew word for “daughter,” not coincidentally also the first syllable of the name ‘‘Bathsheba.”

rsbNotes.title: 2 Sam 12:5
rsbNotes.text: 12:5 the man who has done this deserves to die. Nathan’s parable has succeeded; in pronouncing judgment on the rich man, David has condemned himself. His response is an exclamation, not a legal decision. He mentions first death, then restitution.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Sam 12:6
rsbNotes.text: 12:6 fourfold. Ex. 22:1 orders fourfold restitution for stolen sheep. Some commentators have detected here a hint of David’s subsequent loss of four sons: the first son of Bathsheba (vv. 14, 18), Amnon (13:28, 29), Absalom (18:14, 15), and Adonijah (1 Kin. 2:24, 25).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Sam 12:7–12
rsbNotes.text: 12:7–12 In a manner typical of prophetic judgment speeches (1 Sam. 2:27–36 note), Nathan begins with an accusation including a description of the Lord’s providence (vv. 7, 8) and an accusing question and indictment (v. 9). He concludes by announcing the judgment and the penalties corresponding to the crime.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Sam 12:7
rsbNotes.text: 12:7 I anointed you. Compare Samuel’s indictment of Saul (1 Sam. 15:17).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Sam 12:8
rsbNotes.text: 12:8 your master’s wives. It is uncertain whether this statement is to be taken literally (only one wife and one concubine of Saul are mentioned, 3:7; 1 Sam. 14:50) or simply refers to the full extent of David’s inheritance of Saul’s kingdom. On the matter of kings acquiring their predecessors’ harems, see 3:7 and note.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Sam 12:9
rsbNotes.text:
12:9 evil in his sight. This same idiom appears in 11:25, 27.

You have struck down Uriah. Because David causes Uriah to die in battle, he is as guilty as if he had murdered him with his own hand.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Sam 12:10
rsbNotes.text: 12:10 the sword shall never depart from your house. As Uriah was killed by violence, the house of David will be plagued by violence. Absalom killed Amnon (13:28, 29); Joab killed Absalom (18:14, 15); and Solomon ordered the deaths of Adonijah (1 Kin. 2:24, 25) and Joab (1 Kin. 2:29–34).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Sam 12:11
rsbNotes.text:
12:11 I will raise up evil. The prophecy is fulfilled by the rebellion of Absalom (chs. 15–18).

lie with your wives in the sight of this sun. This prediction is fulfilled in 16:21, 22.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Sam 12:13
rsbNotes.text:
12:13 I have sinned against the Lord. When charged by God’s prophet, David responds with an immediate and unqualified confession; contrast Saul’s confessions in 1 Sam. 15:24, 25, 30 (notes). Ps. 51, according to its superscription, is a fuller picture of David’s repentance.

you shall not die. See notes 11:5; 12:5.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Sam 12:17
rsbNotes.text: 12:17 nor did he eat food with them. See note 1 Sam. 1:7.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Sam 12:20
rsbNotes.text: 12:20 worshiped. Like Eli, but unlike Saul, David humbly accepts the Lord’s discipline (15:26; 16:11; 1 Sam. 3:18 and notes).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Sam 12:23
rsbNotes.text: 12:23 I shall go to him. That is, in the place of the dead (1 Sam. 28:19 note; Gen. 37:35).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Sam 12:24
rsbNotes.text:
12:24 his wife. Here for the first time Bathsheba is called David’s wife (11:3 note).

Solomon. This name is usually considered to be derived from the Hebrew word for “peace” (cf. 1 Chr. 22:9). Another possibility is that it means “replacement”; the birth of Solomon compensates for the loss of the first child.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Sam 12:25
rsbNotes.text: 12:25 Jedidiah. See text note. This name confirms that “the Lord loved him” (v. 24) and bodes well for the future of the Davidic house. Despite the sin of David and his descendants, the Lord’s favor will not be withdrawn (7:14 note).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Sam 12:26–31
rsbNotes.text: 12:26–31 The narrative once again returns to the Ammonite campaign (11:1 and note). This time it is not David who sends Joab, but Joab who sends for David (v. 27).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Sam 12:28
rsbNotes.text: 12:28 called by my name. Joab’s concern may have been prompted by an interest in David’s reputation and the propriety of having the king receive the captive crown.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Sam 12:30
rsbNotes.text: 12:30 the crown of their king. A crown weighing as much as seventy-five pounds (“a talent”) would have been too heavy to wear except for brief ceremonies. The crown could have been from a statue of Milcom or Molech. The same Hebrew letters translated as “their king” could also be read as “Milcom” (i.e., Molech, the chief god of the Ammonites; see 1 Kin. 11:5, 33).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Sam 12:31
rsbNotes.text: 12:31 set them to labor. Subjugation of defeated enemies was common practice for David (8:2) and in the culture of the ancient Near East generally (Ex. 1:11; Josh. 9:22–27; 1 Kin. 9:20, 21).
